title: Birria Quesadilla Dip
description: Rich, cheesy, and deeply savory birria folded into a gooey quesadilla-style dip: shredded stewed beef in a fragrant ancho-guajillo chili broth combined with melty cheeses and browned tortillas for scooping. Slow-simmered spices and aromatics give this communal dip a complex, smoky, slightly tangy flavor perfect for parties or game day.

ingredients.display_name: beef chuck roast, trimmed and cut into 2-inch pieces
ingredients.notes: cut into large chunks for even braising

ingredients.display_name: dried ancho chiles, stems and seeds removed
dried guajillo chiles, stems and seeds removed

ingredients.notes: use half for braise, reserve half for topping if desired
hot when adding to rehydrated chiles
adds brightness to the braising liquid
toasted for extra aroma if desired
use freshly shredded for best melt
cut into wedges for browning and scooping

ingredients.display_name: butter or oil for pan-frying tortillas

ingredients.notes: use to thin dip and serve for dunking

steps.text: Toast dried chiles in a dry skillet over medium heat for 20–30 seconds per side until aromatic but not burned; then remove stems and seeds and transfer to a bowl of hot water to rehydrate for 15 minutes.

Meanwhile, pat beef dry and season with salt and pepper; heat oil in a heavy Dutch oven over medium-high heat and brown beef pieces on all sides in batches to develop color, about 3 minutes per side per batch.
Char tomatoes and onion halves on a hot skillet or under a broiler until blackened in spots, about 6–8 minutes total; peel if desired and set aside.

Drain rehydrated chiles, reserve soaking liquid if desired, and blend chiles with charred tomatoes, onion, garlic, vinegar, oregano, cumin and a cup of hot beef broth until very smooth to create the birria sauce.

Return browned beef to the Dutch oven, add blended sauce, remaining beef broth, bay leaves and any reserved chile soaking liquid as needed to mostly cover meat; bring to a simmer, then reduce heat to low, cover and braise until beef is very tender and shreds easily, about 2 hours.

When beef is tender, remove meat and shred with forks, discard bay leaves; skim fat from braising liquid and reserve 1 cup of consommé for serving; fold shredded beef back into remaining sauce and adjust seasoning with salt and lime juice.

Preheat oven to 425°F (220°C). In a medium bowl, beat softened cream cheese until smooth, then stir in shredded monterey jack and cheddar and fold in a portion of the shredded birria to achieve a thick, scoopable mixture.
Spoon dip into an oven-safe skillet or shallow casserole, smooth top and sprinkle with remaining cheese; bake until cheese is bubbly and golden at edges, about 10–12 minutes.
While dip bakes, brush tortilla wedges with butter or oil and pan-fry in a skillet over medium heat until crisp and golden, about 1–2 minutes per side; keep warm.
Remove dip from oven, garnish with chopped cilantro and a squeeze of lime; serve hot with reserved consommé for dipping and crisped tortilla wedges for scooping.
